title: Problem Formulations for `dsdp`
text: Let \(g(x)\) unknown univariate density function support \(S \subset \mathbb{R}\), \(\mathbb{R}\) denotes set real numbers. \(n\) data set \(\{x_1, \ldots,x_n \}\), realizations random variable whose density \(g(x)\), try estimate density \(g\) using model: \[\begin{equation}   f(x; \alpha, \beta) := p(x; \alpha) \cdot K(x; \beta),   (\#eq:likelihoodfun) \end{equation}\] \(p(x; \alpha)\) univariate nonnegative polynomial \(S\) coefficients \(\alpha\), \(K(x; \beta)\) density function support \(S\). base function, density \(K(x; \beta)\) instance exponential family distributions, namely, Gaussian distribution mean \(\mu\) variance \(\sigma^2\) \[   N(x;\mu, \sigma^2) := \frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2\pi}}   \exp\left(-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right), \quad x \S = (-\infty, \infty).   \] exponential distribution rate parameter \(\lambda > 0\) \[   \mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda) := \lambda e^{-\lambda x}, \quad x \S = [0, \infty).   \] sequel, call Gaussian distribution polynomial Gaussian-based model exponential distribution polynomial Exponential-based model, respectively. One approaches problem maximum likelihood method (MLE). MLEs, estimate model data set \(\{x_1, \ldots,x_n \}\), maximizes product probabilities @ref(eq:likelihoodfun) follows: \[\begin{equation} \max_{\alpha, \beta} \prod_{=1}^{n} f(x_i; \alpha, \beta), (\#eq:mleprod) \end{equation}\] , form log likelihood: \[\begin{equation} \max_{\alpha, \beta} \sum_{=1}^{n} \log f(x_i; \alpha, \beta). (\#eq:mlelog) \end{equation}\] principle MLE good parameters, case, \(\alpha\) \(\beta\), maximize probability realization observed samples \(\{x_1, \ldots,x_n \}\). log likelihood @ref(eq:mlelog) also concerned maximum entropy principle, discussed , example, (Akaike 1973; Konishi Kitagawa 2008). constraint condition, need guarantee \(f\) probability density: \[\begin{equation}   \int_{S} p(x; \alpha) \cdot K(x; \beta) \mathrm{d}x = 1. (\#eq:constraint0) \end{equation}\] computation, customary take minus log likelihood, flips sign objective change maximization problem minimization problem. addition, introduce regularization term \(\mathrm{rAIC}(\alpha, \beta)\) avoid overfitting. discuss AIC later detail. skeleton estimation problem becomes: \[\begin{equation} \begin{aligned} \min_{\alpha, \beta}& -\sum_{=1}^{n} \left[\log p(x_i; \alpha) + \log K(x_i; \beta)\right]   + \mathrm{rAIC}(\alpha, \beta)\\ \text{s.t.  }& \begin{array}{l} p(x;\alpha) \ge 0, \quad x \S,\\ \int_{S} p(x; \alpha) \cdot K(x; \beta) \mathrm{d}x = 1. \end{array} \end{aligned} (\#eq:optskelton) \end{equation}\] compare different models, need consider regularization regarding complexities models; otherwise complex models get better specialization simpler ones, complex models fail generalization. case, adopt Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) (Akaike 1974). AIC, regularization term \(\mathrm{rAIC}(\alpha, \beta)\) put objective @ref(eq:optskelton), adjusted penalizes number free parameters, .e., number parameters minus number constraints. following cases, considering fact number parameters coefficient \(k+1\) polynomials degree \(k\), number parameters Gaussian distribution 2, exponential distribution 1, number constraints @ref(eq:optskelton), presence @ref(eq:constraint0), 1, Gaussian-based model \[ \mathrm{rAIC}(\alpha, \mu, \sigma^2) =  k + 2. \] Exponential-based model \[ \mathrm{rAIC}(\alpha, \lambda) =  k + 1. \] practice, restrict set degrees \(\Theta_{\mathrm{deg}}\) set parameters base functions \(\Theta_\beta\) finite cardinality, compute coefficients \(\alpha\) values using SDP. estimation @ref(eq:optskelton) now concisely presented follows: \[\begin{equation} \begin{aligned} \min_{\begin{subarray}{l}       k \\Theta_{\mathrm{deg}}\\       \beta\\Theta_{\beta}       \end{subarray}}   \min_{\alpha\\mathbb{R}^{k+1}}& -\sum_{=1}^{n}     \left[\log p(x_i; \alpha) + \log K(x_i; \beta)\right] + \mathrm{rAIC}(\alpha, \beta)\\ \text{s.t.  }& \begin{array}{l} p(x;\alpha) \ge 0, \quad x \S,\\ \int_{S} p(x; \alpha) \cdot K(x; \beta) \mathrm{d}x = 1, \end{array} \end{aligned} (\#eq:optskelton2) \end{equation}\] \(\Theta_{\mathrm{deg}}\) \(\Theta_{\beta}\) finite sets.

title: Problem Formulations for `dsdp`
text: section main topic vignette discuss estimation coefficients polynomials fixed degrees polynomials parameters base functions. , introduce several notations. positive integer \(d\), define (d+1)-dimensional column vector \(\textbf{x}_{d} := (1, x,\ldots, x^d)^T\) \(x \\mathbb{R}\), superscript \(\square^T\) denotes transpose vector matrix, also define (d+1) (d+1) matrix \(X_d := \textbf{x}_{d} \textbf{x}_{d}^T\). \(Q, Q_1, Q_2\) \(Q_3\) denote symmetric matrices appropriate sizes, \(Q \succeq 0\) denotes semidefiniteness symmetric matrix \(Q\), .e., eigenvalues \(Q\) nonnegative. \(\mathrm{trace}(Q)\) denotes trace matrix \(Q\), .e., sum diagonal elements \(Q\). Using notations, nonnegativity k-th order polynomials expressed quadratic forms follows. (e.g. (Nesterov 2000; Fushiki, Horiuchi, Tsuchiya 2006)) Let \(p(x; \alpha)\) univariate k-th degree polynomial coefficient \(\alpha\). , exists unique quadratic form corresponding \(\alpha\) following cases. \(p(x; \alpha) \ge 0\) \(S = (-\infty, \infty)\) \(k\) even \(d = \frac{k}{2}\) \[ p(x; \alpha) = \textbf{x}_{d}^T Q \textbf{x}_{d} = \mathrm{trace}(X_d Q), \] unique symmetric matrix \(Q \succeq 0\). \(p(x; \alpha) \ge 0\) \(S = [0, \infty)\) \(k\) odd \(d = \frac{k-1}{2}\) \[ p(x;\alpha) = \textbf{x}_d^T Q_1 \textbf{x}_d + x \cdot \textbf{x}_d^T Q_2 \textbf{x}_d = \mathrm{trace}(X_d Q_1) + \mathrm{trace}(x X_d Q_2) \] unique symmetric matrices \(Q_1, Q_2 \succeq 0\). \(k\) even \(d = \frac{k}{2}\) \[ p(x;\alpha) = \textbf{x}_d^T Q_1 \textbf{x}_d + x \cdot \textbf{x}_{d-1}^T Q_3 \textbf{x}_{d-1} = \mathrm{trace}(X_d Q_1) + \mathrm{trace}(x X_{d-1} Q_3), \] unique symmetric matrices \(Q_1, Q_3 \succeq 0\). Using proposition, positivity constraint @ref(eq:constraint0) k-th order polynomials (\(k \ge 1\)) now written follows. Gaussian-based model \(k\) even \(d = \frac{k}{2}\) \[   \begin{aligned}   1&=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}p(x;\alpha)N(x;\mu, \sigma^2)\mathrm{d}x =    \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \textbf{x}_d^T Q \textbf{x}_d \cdot    N(x;\mu, \sigma^2) \mathrm{d}x \\   &= \mathrm{trace}\left(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}Q  \textbf{x}_d \textbf{x}_d^T   N(x;\mu,\sigma^2)\mathrm{d}x \right)   = \mathrm{trace}\left(Q \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} X_d N(x;\mu, \sigma^2)   \mathrm{d}x\right) \\    &= \mathrm{trace}(Q M),   \end{aligned}   \] \(M := \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} X_{d} N(x; \mu, \sigma^2) \mathrm{d}x\). Exponential-based model \(k\) odd \(d = \frac{k-1}{2}\) \[ \begin{aligned} 1&=\int_{0}^{\infty} p(x;\alpha)\mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda)\mathrm{d}x = \int_{0}^{\infty} (\textbf{x}_d^T Q_1 \textbf{x}_d +     x \cdot \textbf{x}_{d}^T Q_2 \textbf{x}_{d}) \cdot \mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda) \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \mathrm{trace}\left(\int_{0}^{\infty}Q_1  \textbf{x}_d \textbf{x}_d^T \mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda)\mathrm{d}x \right) + \mathrm{trace}\left(\int_{0}^{\infty}Q_2  x \textbf{x}_d \textbf{x}_d^T \mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda)\mathrm{d}x \right)\\ &= \mathrm{trace}\left(Q_1 \int_{0}^{\infty} X_d \mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda)\mathrm{d}x \right) + \mathrm{trace}\left(Q_2 \int_{0}^{\infty} x X_d \mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda)\mathrm{d}x \right) \\ &= \mathrm{trace}(Q_1 M_1) + \mathrm{trace}(Q_2 M_2). \end{aligned} \] \(M_1 := \int_{0}^{\infty} X_{d} \mathrm{Exp}(x; \lambda) \mathrm{d}x\), \(M_2 := \int_{0}^{\infty} x X_{d} \mathrm{Exp}(x; \lambda) \mathrm{d}x\), \(k\) even \(d = \frac{k}{2}\) \[ \begin{aligned} 1&=\int_{0}^{\infty}p(x;\alpha)\mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda)\mathrm{d}x \\ &=\mathrm{trace}\left(Q_1 \int_{0}^{\infty} X_d \mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda)\mathrm{d}x \right) + \mathrm{trace}\left(Q_2 \int_{0}^{\infty} x X_{d-1} \mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda)\mathrm{d}x \right) \\ &= \mathrm{trace}(Q_1 M_1) + \mathrm{trace}(Q_2 M_3), \end{aligned} \] \(M_1 := \int_{0}^{\infty} X_{d} \mathrm{Exp}(x; \lambda) \mathrm{d}x\), \(M_3 := \int_{0}^{\infty} x X_{d-1} \mathrm{Exp}(x; \lambda) \mathrm{d}x\). Note \(M\) moment matrix whose (, j)-th element (+j-2)-th moment Gaussian distribution, similarly, (, j)-th element \(M_1\) (+j-2)-th moment exponential distribution, (, j)-th element \(M_2\) \(M_3\) (+j-1)-th moment distribution. briefly summarize computation moments. Using moment generating function \(M_{X}(t) = E[e^{tX}]\) random variable \(X\), \(E\) expectation operator, k-th degree moment \(m_k\) obtained differentiating \(M_{X}(t)\) respect \(t\) k times \(t=0\), .e., \[ m_k := \left. \frac{d^k M_{X}(t)}{dt^k}\right|_{t=0}. \] Thus, cases, k-th moment obtained follows. Gaussian distribution \(N(x; \mu, \sigma^2)\) moment generating function \(M(t) = e^{\mu t + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2 t^2}\), k-th moment \[\begin{equation}   m_k = \left. \frac{d^k e^{\mu t + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2 t^2}}{dt^k}\right|_{t=0}.   (\#eq:momentgauss)   \end{equation}\] example, show k-th moments \(k=0,1,2,3,4,5\) table exponential distribution \(\mathrm{Exp}(x;\lambda) = \lambda \exp(-\lambda x)\) moment generating function \(M(t) = \frac{\lambda}{\lambda - t}, \text{ } t < \lambda\), k-th moment \[\begin{equation} m_k = \frac{k!}{\lambda^k}.   (\#eq:momentexp)   \end{equation}\] Note since moment becomes easily large \(k\) becomes larger, moment matrix tends highly ill conditioned large degrees polynomials, makes computation coefficients difficult. show SDP formulations density estimation, introduce auxiliary variables \(y_i = p(x_i;\alpha), =1,\ldots,n\) data matrices \(X^{(1)}, \ldots, X^{(n)}\) generated elements data set \(x_1, \ldots, x_n\) described beginning section. Finally MLE @ref(eq:optskelton2) data set \(x_1, \ldots, x_n\) becomes follows. Gaussian-based Model Let \(\Theta_{\mathrm{deg}}\) finite set positive even integer, \(\Theta_{\mu}\) finite set real numbers, \(\Theta_{\sigma}\) finite set positive real numbers. \[ \min_{    \begin{subarray}{l}    k \\Theta_{\mathrm{deg}}\\    \mu\\Theta_{\mu}\\    \sigma\\Theta_{\sigma}    \end{subarray}} \mathrm{SDP}_{\mathrm{Gauss}}(k, \mu, \sigma;x_1,\ldots,x_n) \] \(\mathrm{SDP}_{\mathrm{Gauss}}(k, \mu, \sigma;x_1,\ldots,x_n)\): \[\begin{equation}   \begin{aligned}   \min_{   \begin{subarray}{c}   y_1,\ldots,y_n\\   Q   \end{subarray}} &-\sum_{=1}^{n} \left[ \log y_i + \log N(x_i; \mu, \sigma^2)\right] + (k+2)\\   \text{s.t. }&   \begin{array}{l}   y_i =\mathrm{trace}(X_{d}^{()} Q),\\   y_i \ge 0, \quad =1,\ldots,n,\\   \mathrm{trace}(M Q) = 1,\\   Q \succeq 0,   \end{array}   \end{aligned}   (\#eq:gausssdp)   \end{equation}\] \(d = \frac{k}{2}\), \(Q \\mathbb{R}^{(d+1)\times(d+1)}\) symmetric matrix, \(M\) moment matrix whose (,j) element \(m_{+j-2}\) @ref(eq:momentgauss). Exponential-based model Let \(\Theta_{deg}\) finite set positive integers, \(\Theta_{\lambda}\) finite set positive real numbers. \[ \min_{    \begin{subarray}{l}    k \\Theta_{\mathrm{deg}}\\    \lambda\\Theta_{\lambda}    \end{subarray}} \mathrm{SDP}_{\mathrm{Exp}}(k, \lambda;x_1,\ldots,x_n) \] \(\mathrm{SDP}_{\mathrm{Exp}}(k, \lambda;x_1,\ldots,x_n)\): \(k\) odd \[\begin{equation} \begin{aligned} \min_{ \begin{subarray}{c} y_1,\ldots,y_n\\ Q_1, Q_2 \end{subarray}} &-\sum_{=1}^{n} \left[ \log y_i +\log \mathrm{Exp}(x_i; \lambda)\right] + (k+1)\\ \text{s.t. } & \begin{array}{l} y_i = \mathrm{trace}(X_{d}^{()} Q_1) + \mathrm{trace}(x_i X_{d}^{()} Q_2),\\ y_i \ge 0, \quad =1,\ldots,n,\\ \mathrm{trace}(M_1 Q_1) + \mathrm{trace}(M_2 Q_2) = 1,\\ Q_1 \succeq 0,\\ Q_2 \succeq 0, \end{array} \end{aligned} (\#eq:expsdp1)   \end{equation}\] \(d = \frac{k-1}{2}\), \(Q_1, Q_2 \\mathbb{R}^{(d+1)\times(d+1)}\) symmetric matrices, \(M_1, M_2 \\mathbb{R}^{(d+1)\times(d+1)}\) moment matrices whose (,j) element \(m_{+j-2}\) \(m_{+j-1}\) @ref(eq:momentexp), respectively. \(k\) even \[\begin{equation} \begin{aligned} \min_{ \begin{subarray}{c} y_1,\ldots,y_n\\ Q_1,Q_3 \end{subarray}} &-\sum_{=1}^{n} \left[ \log y_i +\log \mathrm{Exp}(x_i; \lambda)\right] + (k+1)\\ \text{s.t. } & \begin{array}{l} y_i = \mathrm{trace}(X_{d}^{()} Q_1) + \mathrm{trace}(x_i X_{d-1}^{()} Q_3),\\ y_i \ge 0, \quad =1,\ldots,n\\ \mathrm{trace}(M_1 Q_1) + \mathrm{trace}(M_3 Q_3) = 1,\\ Q_1 \succeq 0,\\ Q_3 \succeq 0, \end{array} \end{aligned} (\#eq:expsdp0) \end{equation}\] \(d = \frac{k}{2}\), \(Q_1 \\mathbb{R}^{(d+1)\times(d+1)}\) \(Q_3 \\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}\) symmetric matrices, \(M_1 \\mathbb{R}^{(d+1)\times(d+1)}\) \(M_3 \\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}\) moment matrices whose (,j) element \(m_{+j-2}\) \(m_{+j-1}\) @ref(eq:momentexp), respectively.

title: A Tutorial for `dsdp`
text: main task package dsdp estimate probability density functions data set using maximum likelihood method. models density functions use familiar Gaussian exponential distributions polynomial correction terms. call Gaussian distribution polynomial Gaussian-based model exponential distribution polynomial Exponential-based model, respectively. dsdp seeks parameters Gaussian exponential distributions together degrees polynomials using grid search, coefficients polynomials using variant semidefinite programming(SDP) problems. Detailed discussions SDP problem formulations type SDP problems found vignettes. outline estimation procedure follows. Create Gaussian-based Exponential-based model data set. Explore data set checking statistics histogram Provide set parameters Gaussian exponential distributions degrees polynomials. Estimate coefficients polynomials set parameters check results comparing Akaike Information Criterion(AIC) plotting density functions. Refine parameters repeat 3-4 sufficient estimate obtained. see process step step next section. move , please install import package haven’t yet. Installation done Importing package done package requires ggplot2 displaying histograms density functions. ggplot2 part tidyverse (Wickham et al. 2019), de facto standard data wrangling R. plot method returns ggplot2 objects, plan add title change labels graphs, better import ggplot2 .

title: A Tutorial for `dsdp`
text: continue estimate adding parameters. see estimate.gaussmodel, paramters already estimated skipped. summary estimation : graphs :  confine parameters follows: see summary estimation: graphs follows:  Theoretically, can refine estimation like, stop estimation .
code: ## Do estimation ## Output messages are suppressed for brevity em1 <- estimate(em1, c(3, 4, 5, 6), c(1, 2, 4, 8)) ## Show the summary of results up to 5 summary(em1, nmax=5, estonly=TRUE) ##   ESTIMATION ## Name: mixexpgamma$n200  ##   deg lmd      aic     accuracy ## 1   5   4 183.0460 6.715532e-08 ## 2   6   4 183.9109 9.767674e-08 ## 3   6   2 184.7760 6.458883e-08 ## 4   4   2 185.4038 9.552443e-08 ## 5   4   4 185.4254 9.152939e-08 plot(em1) ## Do estimation ## Output messages are suppressed for brevity em1 <- estimate(em1, c(5, 6), seq(3, 4, by=0.25)) ## Show the summary of results up to 5 summary(em1, nmax=5, estonly=TRUE) ##   ESTIMATION ## Name: mixexpgamma$n200  ##   deg  lmd      aic     accuracy ## 1   5 3.75 183.0320 6.051333e-08 ## 2   5 4.00 183.0460 6.715532e-08 ## 3   5 3.50 183.4025 6.287455e-08 ## 4   5 3.25 183.7779 5.609403e-08 ## 5   5 3.00 183.9076 5.846981e-08 plot(em1)

title: A Tutorial for `dsdp`
text: Using plot.expmodel, can plot cumulative distributions setting cum=TRUE:  details, see ?plot.expmodel. func.expmodel computes values density cumulative distribution desired estimate. example, course, can compute desired estimate designating n=k kth estimate shown summary.expmodel.
code: plot(em1, cum=TRUE) x <- seq(0, 14, by=0.1) ## Compute the density of 1st estimate y_pdf <- func(em1, x, n=1) ## Compute the cumulative distribution of 1st estimate y_cdf <- func(em1, x, cdf=TRUE, n=1)

title: Density Estimation with Semidefinte Programming
text: goal dsdp estimate probability density functions data set using maximum likelihood method. models density functions use familiar Gaussian exponential distributions polynomial correction terms. find optimal model, adopt grid search parameters base functions degrees polynomials, together semidefinite programming coefficients polynomials, model selection done Akaike Information Criterion.

what: dsdp: Density Estimation using Semidefinite Programming — dsdp
title: dsdp: Density Estimation using Semidefinite Programming — dsdp
text: Density estimation Semidefinite Programming. models probability density functions Gaussian exponential distributions polynomial correction terms. Using maximum likelihood method, computes parameters Gaussian exponential distributions together degrees polynomials grid search, coefficients polynomials variant semidefinite programming. adopts Akaike Information Criterion model selection. See vignettes tutorials information.

text: model object expmodel class. deglist vector degrees polynomials. element positive integers. lmdlist vector rate parameters Exponential-based models. element larger 0. recompute TRUE, recomputes results better estimation accuracy. Parameters whose accuracies already attained sufficiently, namely around 1.0e-6, included candidates recomputing. stepsize vector descending order whose values 0 1. small step size supplied, can attain successful estimates, might take iterations. verbose TRUE, shows detailed message SDP solver. ... what: Estimate coefficients of a polynomial in Exponential-based Model — exp_est
title: Estimate coefficients of a polynomial in Exponential-based Model — exp_est
text: Estimate coefficients polynomial Exponential-based model: $$\text{poly}(x; \alpha) \mathrm{Exp}(x; \lambda)$$, \(\alpha\) coefficient vector, \(\lambda\) rate parameter exponential distribution: $$\mathrm{Exp}(x; \lambda) := \lambda e^{-\lambda x}$$. Using data optionally frequencies freq, degree polynomial, rate parameter lmd exponential distribution, computes coefficients polynomial, along Akaike Information Criterion(AIC) accuracy information underlying SDP solver. general, smaller AIC , better model . accuracy around 1e-7 good indication computational result coefficients estimation.

title: Estimate coefficients of a polynomial in Exponential-based Model — exp_est
code: exp_est(deg, lmd, data, freq, verbose, stepvec)

title: Estimate coefficients of a polynomial in Exponential-based Model — exp_est
text: deg degree polynomial, positive even integer. lmd rate parameter exponential distribution, positive. data numeric vector data set estimated. freq numeric vector frequencies data set data. default value NULL, indicates frequencies equally one. freq NULL, length data, values positive integers. verbose TRUE, shows detail information SDP solver. stepvec designates stepsize SDP solver. problem easy, .e., number data set small degree polynomial small, , example, 0.9 might ok. looks difficult, c(0.5, 0.3) might work.

title: Estimate coefficients of a polynomial in Exponential-based Model — exp_est

what: Estimate coefficients of a polynomial in Gaussian-based model — gauss_est
title: Estimate coefficients of a polynomial in Gaussian-based model — gauss_est
text: Estimate coefficients polynomial Gaussian-based model: $$\mathrm{poly}(x, \alpha) N(x; \mu, \sigma^2)$$, \(\alpha\) coefficient vector, \(\mu\) \(\sigma\) mean standard deviation Gaussian distribution: $$N(x; \mu, \sigma^2) :=\frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2\pi}}  \exp\left(-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right) $$ Using data optionally frequencies freq, degree polynomial, mean mu standard deviation sig Gausian distribution, computes coefficients polynomial, along Akaike Information Criterion(AIC) accuracy information underlying SDP solver. general, smaller AIC , better model . accuracy around 1e-7 good indication computational result coefficients estimation.

text: density function mixed Gaussian distributions whose density : $$\frac{0.3}{\sqrt{2 \pi 0.5^2}} \exp\left(\frac{(x+1)^2}{2 \cdot 0.5^2}\right) + \frac{0.7}{\sqrt{2 \pi 0.5^2}} \exp\left(\frac{(x-1)^2}{2 \cdot 0.5^2}\right)$$.

text: numeric vector probabilities given argument x.

what: Probability density function of Exponential-based model — pdf_expmodel
title: Probability density function of Exponential-based model — pdf_expmodel
text: probability density function(PDF) Exponential-based model. underlying routine plot.expmodel compute values PDF. access parameters coefficients object emodel class expmodel, use emodel$result[k, "lmd1"], emodel$coeffs[[k]] index k. index appears leftmost column estimation table generated summary(emodel).

title: Probability density function of Exponential-based model — pdf_expmodel
code: pdf_expmodel(coeff, lmd, x)

title: Probability density function of Exponential-based model — pdf_expmodel
text: coeff coefficient vector increasing order degrees; first element 0th degree, ..., last element largest degree coefficients. lmd rate parameter exponential distribution, positive. x numeric input vector.

title: Probability density function of Exponential-based model — pdf_expmodel
text: numeric vector PDF exponential-based model.

title: Probability density function of Exponential-based model — pdf_expmodel
code: ## Create an object of `expmodel` emodel <- expmodel(mixexpgamma$n200) ## Estimate with degree 4 and rate parameter 2.0 emodel <- estimate(emodel, 4, 2.0) #> (4,2) #> Status: Normal Termination. ## Input vector x <- seq(0, 12, 0.1) ## Output of PDF in above estimation yv <- pdf_expmodel(emodel$coeffs[[1]], emodel$result[1, "lmd1"], x)

what: Probability density function of Gaussian-based model — pdf_gaussmodel
title: Probability density function of Gaussian-based model — pdf_gaussmodel
text: probability density function(PDF) Gaussian model. underlying routine plot.gaussmodel compute values PDF. access parameters coefficients object gmodel class gaussmodel, use gmodel$result[k, "mu1"], gmodel$result[k, "sig1"], gmodel$coeffs[[k]] index k. index appears leftmost column estimation table generated summary(gmodel).

title: Probability density function of Gaussian-based model — pdf_gaussmodel
code: pdf_gaussmodel(coeff, mu, sig, x)

title: Probability density function of Gaussian-based model — pdf_gaussmodel
text: coeff coefficient vector increasing order degrees; first element 0th degree, ..., last element largest degree coefficients. mu mean Gaussian distribution. sig standard deviation Gaussian distribution, positive. x numeric input vector.

title: Probability density function of Gaussian-based model — pdf_gaussmodel
text: numeric vector PDF Gaussian-based distribution.

title: Probability density function of Gaussian-based model — pdf_gaussmodel
code: ## Create an object of `gaussmodel` gmodel <- gaussmodel(mix2gauss$n200) ## Estimate with a degree 6, a mean 0, and standard deviations 0.5 gmodel <- estimate(gmodel, 6, 0, 0.5) #> (6,0,0.5) #> Status: Normal Termination. ## Input vector x <- seq(-3, 3, 0.1) ## Output of PDF in above estimation yv <- pdf_gaussmodel(gmodel$coeffs[[1]], gmodel$result[1, "mu1"],  gmodel$result[1, "sig1"], x)

what: Substitute a coefficient of polynomial — polyaxb
title: Substitute a coefficient of polynomial — polyaxb
text: Substitute coefficient polynomial *x + b. polynomial coefficient vector \(poly(x; coeff)\), compute coefficient vector $$poly(*x + b; coeff).$$

title: Substitute a coefficient of polynomial — polyaxb
code: polyaxb(coeff, c, a, b)

title: Substitute a coefficient of polynomial — polyaxb
text: coeff coefficient vector increasing order degrees; first element 0th degree, ..., last element largest degree coefficients. c multiple factor constant applied coefficients. coefficient 1st degree *x + b. b coefficient 0th degree *x + b.

title: Substitute a coefficient of polynomial — polyaxb
text: substituted coefficient.

title: Substitute a coefficient of polynomial — polyaxb
code: coeff <- c(2, -2, 1) a <- 1.1 b <- 1.2 coeff1 <- c(b, a) coeff2 <- polyaxb(coeff, 1, a, b) xv <- c(1, 2, 3) ## a*x + b yv1 <- eval_poly(coeff1, xv) ## polynomial(a*x + b, coeff) yv2 <- eval_poly(coeff, yv1) ## polynomial(x, coeff2) yv <- eval_poly(coeff2, xv) ## This value is nearly 0 in the presence of rounding errors yv - yv2 #> [1]  8.881784e-16 -8.881784e-16  0.000000e+00
